chat: pim-06: "The more I think about this activity, the more I wonder if we are supposed to be collaboratively writing an end to the story. "
chat_history:
pim-06: "If the princess possesses the same semi-barbaric trait as her father, then it would seem she directed her lover to the door with the tiger. "
pim-06: "Either way she must love without him, but is she open-hearted enough to allow for him to love another?"
pim-06: "It doesn't appear so. For instance, she discloses great agony, jealousy, and stress about the potential wedding between her lover and the lady behind the door;"
pim-06: "however, she only comments that a tiger would bring shrieks and blood. From her revealed thoughts, she is "
pim-06: "mor"
pim-06: "more upset with the prospect of him belonging to another, and so it is clear,"
pim-06: "given the two terrible choices,"
pim-06: "she would send him to his death."
pim-06: "If the King were to discover that his daughter broke the law by secretly sending her lover towards the door on the right"
pim-06: "he would have to send his daughter to the arena for a judgement. "
pim-06: "I would imagine,"
pim-06: "given that it is stressed he is semi-barbaric, he would choose not to send his daughter, whom he loves so dearly, to her potential death."
pim-06: "However, I also do not"
pim-06: "ima"
pim-06: "imagine this to be the catalyst that ends his idea of public punishment. "
pim-06: "Perhaps, instead of sending his daughter to the arena, he would send the person who gave her the information about the two doors instead."
pim-06: " It could be argued that the informant is more guilty than the princess and is sent to show the kingdom the consequence of such behaviors."
pim-06: "(Sorry it came out as three separate messages! For some reason, it wouldn't post my full response at once.)"
pim-04: "I agree with Ashely "
pim-04: " that the Princess's barbaric traits will lead the princess to send her lover to his death."
pim-04: "She exhibits immaturity and cruelty by fixating on imagined flirtations between "the lady" and the princess's lover."
pim-04: "The story also leads me to think that she is accustomed to having her every wish granted by her father and that she never learned the benefits of compassion."
pim-04: "I also agree with Ashley"
pim-04: "that the king's adoration of his daughter would stop him from sending his daughter into the arena."
pim-04: "I had orgininally thought that the king would either keep her secret out of love for his daughter, or out of barbaric pride that she sent her lover to his grizzly death, or a combination of the two. "
pim-04: "If the secret was shared with the community, I also think that it would be her informant that would be punished."
pim-04: "I had not considered Ashley's idea that this experience might be an "
pim-04: "opportun"
pim-04: "I had not considered Ashley's idea that this experience might be an opportunity for the king to re-examine the practice."
pim-04: " I like this idea!"

topic: Part 1: What happens next? What is behind the door, the lady or the tiger?  Part 2: Later, the King discovers that his daughter has broken the law.  How does the King respond? What happens?
message: Good idea!
question: None
chat: pim-12: "Good idea!"
chat_history:
pim-11: "What do you guys think? "
pim-11: "Do you think that she kills him or saves him?"
pim-11: "What would you do in her place?"
pim-11: "I kind of think that even though she is angry and jealous, she would ultimately save him. "
pim-11: "I think that overall the weight of her conscious would have kept her from sending him to his death for falling in love with her."
pim-11: "After all, it is a two way road and she is being punished right along with him for getting caught by the king as well."
pim-11: " I also think that even if the king finds out that she knew the doors he will know that either choice that she makes is a punishment in its own right. She suffers either way "
pim-11: "w"
pim-11: "And what if the king already knew that she had broken the law. "
pim-11: "Perhaps he planned it so that she would be the one to make the decision in the end as no one has ever known what's behind the doors before"
pim-11: "Maybe this was her punishment."
pim-11: "Knowing she could save him from death, but still lose him in the end."
pim-11: "It would be just a thing that this King would do I think."
pim-12: "Kyra, those are some good thoughts! "
pim-12: "I'm kind of on the fence about whether she saves him or not."
pim-12: " I think that she may dislike the idea that he marries another more than him dying."
pim-12: "So I'm leaning more toward she sends him to the tiger's door."
pim-12: "But I do also think that it is possible that the King could be in on it too. "
pim-12: "He could know that she knows which door is which and he seems like the type of king to enjoy that punishment"
pim-11: "Emilie I can see that. "
pim-11: "What would you do in her place?"
pim-11: "Not what do you think she would do, but what would you do if you were in the situation? "
pim-11: "I know I wouldn't be able to live with myself if I knew I was the reason the person I loved was killed in such a painful manner"
pim-11: " It would hurt worse to know his death was my fault than to know that he was happy with someone else. "
pim-11: "I think I'd find it easier to move on and live if he was still alive."
pim-11: "I mean there are other guys out there after all."
pim-12: "I agree."
pim-12: " Personally, I would save him. "
pim-12: "I'd rather be sad for a little while that the person I loved married someone else, than let them get killed. "
pim-12: "I would feel guilty for the rest of my life."
pim-12: "And that's true! "
pim-12: "There are other guys out there so even if he was the most handsome and all that,"
pim-12: "I'm sure I would eventually get over him being with someone else"
pim-12: "I think if I misled him to choose the tiger's door, I would feel like I committed a murder myself"

pim-11: "But I'm not sure how this princess would think."

pim-12: "I also got the sense that she would point her lover to the tiger's door, but now the more that I think about it, I think she would send him to the other woman."
pim-12: "I liked what you mentioned earlier Kyra"
pim-12: "about how she may have felt guilty."
pim-12: "As for Part 2, I have a theory. "
pim-12: "I think that when the King discovers his daughter broke the law, he would still make her go through the arena."
pim-12: "BUT, he'd tell her which door leads to a man and which leads to the tiger, thinking that she will obviously choose to marry and live."
pim-12: "HOWEVER, she is so distraught about losing the love of her life that she actually chooses the tiger's door on purpose."
pim-12: "This could either cause the King to become even more barbaric or to stop these trials all together"
pim-12: "But that's just what I was thinking."
pim-12: " I'm definitely okay with another approach that we can all agree on"
pim-11: "Oooo I like that idea of how he might send her to the arena and then tell her which is behind each door. "
pim-11: "This gives her a chance at potential happiness or, if she is feeling miserable and depressed, may want to go through with the tiger!"
pim-11: "That's certainly an interesting way to look at the potential of that kind of ending."
pim-11: "And I almost think if we can't decide we might just flip a coin "
pim-11: "lol "

topic: Part 1: What happens next? What is behind the door, the lady or the tiger?  Part 2: Later, the King discovers that his daughter has broken the law.  How does the King respond? What happens?

question: None
chat: pim-11: "Or we could take turns writing out a paragraph and jump one it from the last person's response."
chat_history:
pim-11: "What do you guys think? "
pim-11: "Do you think that she kills him or saves him?"
pim-11: "What would you do in her place?"
pim-11: "I kind of think that even though she is angry and jealous, she would ultimately save him. "
pim-11: "I think that overall the weight of her conscious would have kept her from sending him to his death for falling in love with her."
pim-11: "After all, it is a two way road and she is being punished right along with him for getting caught by the king as well."
pim-11: " I also think that even if the king finds out that she knew the doors he will know that either choice that she makes is a punishment in its own right. She suffers either way "
pim-11: "w"
pim-11: "And what if the king already knew that she had broken the law. "
pim-11: "Perhaps he planned it so that she would be the one to make the decision in the end as no one has ever known what's behind the doors before"
pim-11: "Maybe this was her punishment."
pim-11: "Knowing she could save him from death, but still lose him in the end."
pim-11: "It would be just a thing that this King would do I think."
pim-12: "Kyra, those are some good thoughts! "
pim-12: "I'm kind of on the fence about whether she saves him or not."
pim-12: " I think that she may dislike the idea that he marries another more than him dying."
pim-12: "So I'm leaning more toward she sends him to the tiger's door."
pim-12: "But I do also think that it is possible that the King could be in on it too. "
pim-12: "He could know that she knows which door is which and he seems like the type of king to enjoy that punishment"
pim-11: "Emilie I can see that. "
pim-11: "What would you do in her place?"
pim-11: "Not what do you think she would do, but what would you do if you were in the situation? "
pim-11: "I know I wouldn't be able to live with myself if I knew I was the reason the person I loved was killed in such a painful manner"
pim-11: " It would hurt worse to know his death was my fault than to know that he was happy with someone else. "
pim-11: "I think I'd find it easier to move on and live if he was still alive."
pim-11: "I mean there are other guys out there after all."
pim-12: "I agree."
pim-12: " Personally, I would save him. "
pim-12: "I'd rather be sad for a little while that the person I loved married someone else, than let them get killed. "
pim-12: "I would feel guilty for the rest of my life."
pim-12: "And that's true! "
pim-12: "There are other guys out there so even if he was the most handsome and all that,"
pim-12: "I'm sure I would eventually get over him being with someone else"

chat: pim-11: "Glad you like that idea "
chat_history:
pim-11: "What do you guys think? "
pim-11: "Do you think that she kills him or saves him?"
pim-11: "What would you do in her place?"
pim-11: "I kind of think that even though she is angry and jealous, she would ultimately save him. "
pim-11: "I think that overall the weight of her conscious would have kept her from sending him to his death for falling in love with her."
pim-11: "After all, it is a two way road and she is being punished right along with him for getting caught by the king as well."
pim-11: " I also think that even if the king finds out that she knew the doors he will know that either choice that she makes is a punishment in its own right. She suffers either way "
pim-11: "w"
pim-11: "And what if the king already knew that she had broken the law. "
pim-11: "Perhaps he planned it so that she would be the one to make the decision in the end as no one has ever known what's behind the doors before"
pim-11: "Maybe this was her punishment."
pim-11: "Knowing she could save him from death, but still lose him in the end."
pim-11: "It would be just a thing that this King would do I think."
pim-12: "Kyra, those are some good thoughts! "
pim-12: "I'm kind of on the fence about whether she saves him or not."
pim-12: " I think that she may dislike the idea that he marries another more than him dying."
pim-12: "So I'm leaning more toward she sends him to the tiger's door."
pim-12: "But I do also think that it is possible that the King could be in on it too. "
pim-12: "He could know that she knows which door is which and he seems like the type of king to enjoy that punishment"
pim-11: "Emilie I can see that. "
pim-11: "What would you do in her place?"
pim-11: "Not what do you think she would do, but what would you do if you were in the situation? "
pim-11: "I know I wouldn't be able to live with myself if I knew I was the reason the person I loved was killed in such a painful manner"
pim-11: " It would hurt worse to know his death was my fault than to know that he was happy with someone else. "
pim-11: "I think I'd find it easier to move on and live if he was still alive."
pim-11: "I mean there are other guys out there after all."
pim-12: "I agree."
pim-12: " Personally, I would save him. "
pim-12: "I'd rather be sad for a little while that the person I loved married someone else, than let them get killed. "
pim-12: "I would feel guilty for the rest of my life."
pim-12: "And that's true! "
pim-12: "There are other guys out there so even if he was the most handsome and all that,"
pim-12: "I'm sure I would eventually get over him being with someone else"
pim-12: "I think if I misled him to choose the tiger's door, I would feel like I committed a murder myself"
pim-11: "I agree with that so much! "
pim-11: "But I'm not sure how this princess would think."
pim-11: "Do we know how many people are part of this group? "
pim-11: "We can try to get in touch with them and decide how we wat to write out the answer"
pim-12: "I'm not sure! "
pim-12: "I tried looking for a "particpants" button or something and I couldn't find one."
pim-11: "I couldn't either."
pim-11: "I sent an email to the coordinator and I hope to hear back from them, but I wouldn't mind setting up a discussion in our class page too"
pim-11: "You're here for LIS6303 or for another class?"
pim-12: "I'm also in LIS6303!"
pim-11: "okay awesome! "
pim-11: "I'm going to create a discussion called Book Club 4 and see if we can see if there is anyone else who is part of that group."
pim-12: "Good idea!"
pim-12: "So how do you guys think we should end it?"
pim-11: "I'm honestly okay with either ending, "
pim-11: "but I think we should incorporate the King mentioning that he helped feed his daughter the information on what was behind each door. "
pim-11: "That's just my opinion though."
pim-11: "Also, I got an email letting us know that Elias Royal is also a part of our group. "
pim-11: "I want to wait to see what they think about how the ending should go as well."
pim-11: "How do you think it should end, Emilie?"
pim-12: "Of course, we should all definitely have a chance to contribute."
pim-12: "I'm also okay with either ending for Part 1 as well. "
pim-12: "My initial thoughts were that the princess knows what's behind each of the doors because the King had told her or she figured it out from overhearing him talk about the punishment."
pim-12: "I also got the sense that she would point her lover to the tiger's door, but now the more that I think about it, I think she would send him to the other woman."
pim-12: "I liked what you mentioned earlier Kyra"
pim-12: "about how she may have felt guilty."
pim-12: "As for Part 2, I have a theory. "
pim-12: "I think that when the King discovers his daughter broke the law, he would still make her go through the arena."
pim-12: "BUT, he'd tell her which door leads to a man and which leads to the tiger, thinking that she will obviously choose to marry and live."
pim-12: "HOWEVER, she is so distraught about losing the love of her life that she actually chooses the tiger's door on purpose."
pim-12: "This could either cause the King to become even more barbaric or to stop these trials all together"
pim-12: "But that's just what I was thinking."
pim-12: " I'm definitely okay with another approach that we can all agree on"
pim-11: "Oooo I like that idea of how he might send her to the arena and then tell her which is behind each door. "
pim-11: "This gives her a chance at potential happiness or, if she is feeling miserable and depressed, may want to go through with the tiger!"
pim-11: "That's certainly an interesting way to look at the potential of that kind of ending."
pim-11: "And I almost think if we can't decide we might just flip a coin "
pim-11: "lol "
pim-11: "(I've been playing dnd too much and it has influenced my writing)"
pim-11: "Or we could take turns writing out a paragraph and jump one it from the last person's response."
pim-12: "Flipping a coin may not be the worst idea, honestly! "
pim-12: "I like the idea of writing a paragraph or a few sentences and then bouncing off from there. "
pim-12: "That's fun"

pim-11: "w"
pim-11: "And what if the king already knew that she had broken the law. "
pim-11: "Perhaps he planned it so that she would be the one to make the decision in the end as no one has ever known what's behind the doors before"
pim-11: "Maybe this was her punishment."
pim-11: "Knowing she could save him from death, but still lose him in the end."
pim-11: "It would be just a thing that this King would do I think."
pim-12: "Kyra, those are some good thoughts! "
pim-12: "I'm kind of on the fence about whether she saves him or not."
pim-12: " I think that she may dislike the idea that he marries another more than him dying."
pim-12: "So I'm leaning more toward she sends him to the tiger's door."
pim-12: "But I do also think that it is possible that the King could be in on it too. "
pim-12: "He could know that she knows which door is which and he seems like the type of king to enjoy that punishment"
pim-11: "Emilie I can see that. "
pim-11: "What would you do in her place?"
pim-11: "Not what do you think she would do, but what would you do if you were in the situation? "
pim-11: "I know I wouldn't be able to live with myself if I knew I was the reason the person I loved was killed in such a painful manner"
pim-11: " It would hurt worse to know his death was my fault than to know that he was happy with someone else. "
pim-11: "I think I'd find it easier to move on and live if he was still alive."
pim-11: "I mean there are other guys out there after all."
pim-12: "I agree."
pim-12: " Personally, I would save him. "
pim-12: "I'd rather be sad for a little while that the person I loved married someone else, than let them get killed. "
pim-12: "I would feel guilty for the rest of my life."
pim-12: "And that's true! "
pim-12: "There are other guys out there so even if he was the most handsome and all that,"
pim-12: "I'm sure I would eventually get over him being with someone else"
pim-12: "I think if I misled him to choose the tiger's door, I would feel like I committed a murder myself"
pim-11: "I agree with that so much! "
pim-11: "But I'm not sure how this princess would think."
pim-11: "Do we know how many people are part of this group? "
pim-11: "We can try to get in touch with them and decide how we wat to write out the answer"
pim-12: "I'm not sure! "
pim-12: "I tried looking for a "particpants" button or something and I couldn't find one."
pim-11: "I couldn't either."
pim-11: "I sent an email to the coordinator and I hope to hear back from them, but I wouldn't mind setting up a discussion in our class page too"
pim-11: "You're here for LIS6303 or for another class?"
pim-12: "I'm also in LIS6303!"
pim-11: "okay awesome! "
pim-11: "I'm going to create a discussion called Book Club 4 and see if we can see if there is anyone else who is part of that group."
pim-12: "Good idea!"
pim-12: "So how do you guys think we should end it?"
pim-11: "I'm honestly okay with either ending, "
pim-11: "but I think we should incorporate the King mentioning that he helped feed his daughter the information on what was behind each door. "
pim-11: "That's just my opinion though."
pim-11: "Also, I got an email letting us know that Elias Royal is also a part of our group. "
pim-11: "I want to wait to see what they think about how the ending should go as well."
pim-11: "How do you think it should end, Emilie?"
pim-12: "Of course, we should all definitely have a chance to contribute."
pim-12: "I'm also okay with either ending for Part 1 as well. "
pim-12: "My initial thoughts were that the princess knows what's behind each of the doors because the King had told her or she figured it out from overhearing him talk about the punishment."
pim-12: "I also got the sense that she would point her lover to the tiger's door, but now the more that I think about it, I think she would send him to the other woman."
pim-12: "I liked what you mentioned earlier Kyra"
pim-12: "about how she may have felt guilty."
pim-12: "As for Part 2, I have a theory. "
pim-12: "I think that when the King discovers his daughter broke the law, he would still make her go through the arena."
pim-12: "BUT, he'd tell her which door leads to a man and which leads to the tiger, thinking that she will obviously choose to marry and live."
pim-12: "HOWEVER, she is so distraught about losing the love of her life that she actually chooses the tiger's door on purpose."
pim-12: "This could either cause the King to become even more barbaric or to stop these trials all together"
pim-12: "But that's just what I was thinking."
pim-12: " I'm definitely okay with another approach that we can all agree on"
pim-11: "Oooo I like that idea of how he might send her to the arena and then tell her which is behind each door. "
pim-11: "This gives her a chance at potential happiness or, if she is feeling miserable and depressed, may want to go through with the tiger!"
pim-11: "That's certainly an interesting way to look at the potential of that kind of ending."
pim-11: "And I almost think if we can't decide we might just flip a coin "
pim-11: "lol "
pim-11: "(I've been playing dnd too much and it has influenced my writing)"
pim-11: "Or we could take turns writing out a paragraph and jump one it from the last person's response."
pim-12: "Flipping a coin may not be the worst idea, honestly! "
pim-12: "I like the idea of writing a paragraph or a few sentences and then bouncing off from there. "
pim-12: "That's fun"
pim-11: "Glad you like that idea "
pim-11: ":D"
pim-11: "I think it would be fun too!"
pim-11: "Oooo I have another idea! What if the princess sends the man to the tiger and right out tells her father she did it and wants a trial. Then because he loves her he begs her to choose the door with the young man he picks for her, but she chooses the tiger."

chat: pim-12: "Let's hope I do as well on part 2!!"
chat_history:
pim-11: "What do you guys think? "
pim-11: "Do you think that she kills him or saves him?"
pim-11: "What would you do in her place?"
pim-11: "I kind of think that even though she is angry and jealous, she would ultimately save him. "
pim-11: "I think that overall the weight of her conscious would have kept her from sending him to his death for falling in love with her."
pim-11: "After all, it is a two way road and she is being punished right along with him for getting caught by the king as well."
pim-11: " I also think that even if the king finds out that she knew the doors he will know that either choice that she makes is a punishment in its own right. She suffers either way "
pim-11: "w"
pim-11: "And what if the king already knew that she had broken the law. "
pim-11: "Perhaps he planned it so that she would be the one to make the decision in the end as no one has ever known what's behind the doors before"
pim-11: "Maybe this was her punishment."
pim-11: "Knowing she could save him from death, but still lose him in the end."
pim-11: "It would be just a thing that this King would do I think."
pim-12: "Kyra, those are some good thoughts! "
pim-12: "I'm kind of on the fence about whether she saves him or not."
pim-12: " I think that she may dislike the idea that he marries another more than him dying."
pim-12: "So I'm leaning more toward she sends him to the tiger's door."
pim-12: "But I do also think that it is possible that the King could be in on it too. "
pim-12: "He could know that she knows which door is which and he seems like the type of king to enjoy that punishment"
pim-11: "Emilie I can see that. "
pim-11: "What would you do in her place?"
pim-11: "Not what do you think she would do, but what would you do if you were in the situation? "
pim-11: "I know I wouldn't be able to live with myself if I knew I was the reason the person I loved was killed in such a painful manner"
pim-11: " It would hurt worse to know his death was my fault than to know that he was happy with someone else. "
pim-11: "I think I'd find it easier to move on and live if he was still alive."
pim-11: "I mean there are other guys out there after all."
pim-12: "I agree."
pim-12: " Personally, I would save him. "
pim-12: "I'd rather be sad for a little while that the person I loved married someone else, than let them get killed. "
pim-12: "I would feel guilty for the rest of my life."
pim-12: "And that's true! "
pim-12: "There are other guys out there so even if he was the most handsome and all that,"
pim-12: "I'm sure I would eventually get over him being with someone else"
pim-12: "I think if I misled him to choose the tiger's door, I would feel like I committed a murder myself"
pim-11: "I agree with that so much! "
pim-11: "But I'm not sure how this princess would think."
pim-11: "Do we know how many people are part of this group? "
pim-11: "We can try to get in touch with them and decide how we wat to write out the answer"
pim-12: "I'm not sure! "
pim-12: "I tried looking for a "particpants" button or something and I couldn't find one."
pim-11: "I couldn't either."
pim-11: "I sent an email to the coordinator and I hope to hear back from them, but I wouldn't mind setting up a discussion in our class page too"
pim-11: "You're here for LIS6303 or for another class?"
pim-12: "I'm also in LIS6303!"
pim-11: "okay awesome! "
pim-11: "I'm going to create a discussion called Book Club 4 and see if we can see if there is anyone else who is part of that group."
pim-12: "Good idea!"
pim-12: "So how do you guys think we should end it?"
pim-11: "I'm honestly okay with either ending, "
pim-11: "but I think we should incorporate the King mentioning that he helped feed his daughter the information on what was behind each door. "
pim-11: "That's just my opinion though."
pim-11: "Also, I got an email letting us know that Elias Royal is also a part of our group. "
pim-11: "I want to wait to see what they think about how the ending should go as well."
pim-11: "How do you think it should end, Emilie?"
pim-12: "Of course, we should all definitely have a chance to contribute."
pim-12: "I'm also okay with either ending for Part 1 as well. "
pim-12: "My initial thoughts were that the princess knows what's behind each of the doors because the King had told her or she figured it out from overhearing him talk about the punishment."
pim-12: "I also got the sense that she would point her lover to the tiger's door, but now the more that I think about it, I think she would send him to the other woman."
pim-12: "I liked what you mentioned earlier Kyra"
pim-12: "about how she may have felt guilty."
pim-12: "As for Part 2, I have a theory. "
pim-12: "I think that when the King discovers his daughter broke the law, he would still make her go through the arena."
pim-12: "BUT, he'd tell her which door leads to a man and which leads to the tiger, thinking that she will obviously choose to marry and live."
pim-12: "HOWEVER, she is so distraught about losing the love of her life that she actually chooses the tiger's door on purpose."
pim-12: "This could either cause the King to become even more barbaric or to stop these trials all together"
pim-12: "But that's just what I was thinking."
pim-12: " I'm definitely okay with another approach that we can all agree on"
pim-11: "Oooo I like that idea of how he might send her to the arena and then tell her which is behind each door. "
pim-11: "This gives her a chance at potential happiness or, if she is feeling miserable and depressed, may want to go through with the tiger!"
pim-11: "That's certainly an interesting way to look at the potential of that kind of ending."
pim-11: "And I almost think if we can't decide we might just flip a coin "
pim-11: "lol "
pim-11: "(I've been playing dnd too much and it has influenced my writing)"
pim-11: "Or we could take turns writing out a paragraph and jump one it from the last person's response."
pim-12: "Flipping a coin may not be the worst idea, honestly! "
pim-12: "I like the idea of writing a paragraph or a few sentences and then bouncing off from there. "
pim-12: "That's fun"
pim-11: "Glad you like that idea "
pim-11: ":D"
pim-11: "I think it would be fun too!"
pim-11: "Oooo I have another idea! What if the princess sends the man to the tiger and right out tells her father she did it and wants a trial. Then because he loves her he begs her to choose the door with the young man he picks for her, but she chooses the tiger."
pim-12: "That's a creative idea!"
pim-12: " I like it"
pim-12: "Kyra, I LOVE what you did for part 1!! "
pim-12: "That's some amazing writing! "

topic: Part 1: What happens next? What is behind the door, the lady or the tiger?  Part 2: Later, the King discovers that his daughter has broken the law.  How does the King respond? What happens?

chat_history:
pim-11: "What do you guys think? "
pim-11: "Do you think that she kills him or saves him?"
pim-11: "What would you do in her place?"
pim-11: "I kind of think that even though she is angry and jealous, she would ultimately save him. "
pim-11: "I think that overall the weight of her conscious would have kept her from sending him to his death for falling in love with her."
pim-11: "After all, it is a two way road and she is being punished right along with him for getting caught by the king as well."

pim-11: "Perhaps he planned it so that she would be the one to make the decision in the end as no one has ever known what's behind the doors before"

pim-11: "Knowing she could save him from death, but still lose him in the end."
pim-11: "It would be just a thing that this King would do I think."

pim-12: "I'm kind of on the fence about whether she saves him or not."

pim-11: " It would hurt worse to know his death was my fault than to know that he was happy with someone else. "

pim-11: "I mean there are other guys out there after all."

pim-12: " Personally, I would save him. "

pim-12: "I would feel guilty for the rest of my life."
pim-12: "And that's true! "

pim-12: "I'm sure I would eventually get over him being with someone else"

pim-12: "So how do you guys think we should end it?"
pim-11: "I'm honestly okay with either ending, "
pim-11: "but I think we should incorporate the King mentioning that he helped feed his daughter the information on what was behind each door. "
pim-11: "That's just my opinion though."
pim-11: "Also, I got an email letting us know that Elias Royal is also a part of our group. "
pim-11: "I want to wait to see what they think about how the ending should go as well."
pim-11: "How do you think it should end, Emilie?"
pim-12: "Of course, we should all definitely have a chance to contribute."
pim-12: "I'm also okay with either ending for Part 1 as well. "
pim-12: "My initial thoughts were that the princess knows what's behind each of the doors because the King had told her or she figured it out from overhearing him talk about the punishment."
pim-12: "I also got the sense that she would point her lover to the tiger's door, but now the more that I think about it, I think she would send him to the other woman."
pim-12: "I liked what you mentioned earlier Kyra"
pim-12: "about how she may have felt guilty."
pim-12: "As for Part 2, I have a theory. "
pim-12: "I think that when the King discovers his daughter broke the law, he would still make her go through the arena."
pim-12: "BUT, he'd tell her which door leads to a man and which leads to the tiger, thinking that she will obviously choose to marry and live."
pim-12: "HOWEVER, she is so distraught about losing the love of her life that she actually chooses the tiger's door on purpose."
pim-12: "This could either cause the King to become even more barbaric or to stop these trials all together"
pim-12: "But that's just what I was thinking."
pim-12: " I'm definitely okay with another approach that we can all agree on"
pim-11: "Oooo I like that idea of how he might send her to the arena and then tell her which is behind each door. "
pim-11: "This gives her a chance at potential happiness or, if she is feeling miserable and depressed, may want to go through with the tiger!"
pim-11: "That's certainly an interesting way to look at the potential of that kind of ending."
pim-11: "And I almost think if we can't decide we might just flip a coin "
pim-11: "lol "
pim-11: "(I've been playing dnd too much and it has influenced my writing)"
pim-11: "Or we could take turns writing out a paragraph and jump one it from the last person's response."
pim-12: "Flipping a coin may not be the worst idea, honestly! "
pim-12: "I like the idea of writing a paragraph or a few sentences and then bouncing off from there. "
pim-12: "That's fun"
pim-11: "Glad you like that idea "
pim-11: ":D"
pim-11: "I think it would be fun too!"
pim-11: "Oooo I have another idea! What if the princess sends the man to the tiger and right out tells her father she did it and wants a trial. Then because he loves her he begs her to choose the door with the young man he picks for her, but she chooses the tiger."
pim-12: "That's a creative idea!"
pim-12: " I like it"
pim-12: "Kyra, I LOVE what you did for part 1!! "
pim-12: "That's some amazing writing! "
pim-12: "Let's hope I do as well on part 2!!"

topic: Part 1: What happens next? What is behind the door, the lady or the tiger?  Part 2: Later, the King discovers that his daughter has broken the law.  How does the King respond? What happens?
message: So I don't know.
question: None
chat: pim-11: "So I don't know. "
chat_history:
pim-11: "What do you guys think? "
pim-11: "Do you think that she kills him or saves him?"
pim-11: "What would you do in her place?"
pim-11: "I kind of think that even though she is angry and jealous, she would ultimately save him. "
pim-11: "I think that overall the weight of her conscious would have kept her from sending him to his death for falling in love with her."
pim-11: "After all, it is a two way road and she is being punished right along with him for getting caught by the king as well."
pim-11: " I also think that even if the king finds out that she knew the doors he will know that either choice that she makes is a punishment in its own right. She suffers either way "
pim-11: "w"
pim-11: "And what if the king already knew that she had broken the law. "
pim-11: "Perhaps he planned it so that she would be the one to make the decision in the end as no one has ever known what's behind the doors before"
pim-11: "Maybe this was her punishment."
pim-11: "Knowing she could save him from death, but still lose him in the end."
pim-11: "It would be just a thing that this King would do I think."
pim-12: "Kyra, those are some good thoughts! "
pim-12: "I'm kind of on the fence about whether she saves him or not."
pim-12: " I think that she may dislike the idea that he marries another more than him dying."
pim-12: "So I'm leaning more toward she sends him to the tiger's door."
pim-12: "But I do also think that it is possible that the King could be in on it too. "
pim-12: "He could know that she knows which door is which and he seems like the type of king to enjoy that punishment"
pim-11: "Emilie I can see that. "
pim-11: "What would you do in her place?"
pim-11: "Not what do you think she would do, but what would you do if you were in the situation? "
pim-11: "I know I wouldn't be able to live with myself if I knew I was the reason the person I loved was killed in such a painful manner"
pim-11: " It would hurt worse to know his death was my fault than to know that he was happy with someone else. "

pim-11: "I mean there are other guys out there after all."

pim-12: " Personally, I would save him. "

pim-12: "And that's true! "

message: Hi Diane Gonzalez and Deborah Evans. I'm sorry to be so late joining the conversation. If I ponder too long, I'll never come to a conclusion, so I'm going to write my first thoughts. I share your  he's barbaric, and he's fine doling out punishment to his own daughter, as his punishment of her lover has in effect punished her as well. take that the princess will direct the gentleman to the tiger - she's lost him either way and her jealousy and barbarism are too great. On the other hand, the text describes her and the gentleman as having one soul, which I take to mean he would know if she chose the tiger, in which case he'd choose the other door, yet he doesn't. So does that mean she didn't choose the tiger? Or that he'd rather die than be with another woman? For Part 2, I believe the king likely would not show mercy, even to his own daughter, as he has consistently relied on this method of justice

topic: Part 1: What happens next? What is behind the door, the lady or the tiger?  Part 2: Later, the King discovers that his daughter has broken the law.  How does the King respond? What happens?
message: I believe she tells him to open the door with the tiger. This isn't a question of whether or not she loves him, or even trusts him. It's clearly written that she loves him dearly, and his trustworthiness isn't something to consider so heavily since she will lose him heavily. I think she points him to the tiger because of how much more thought she put into the aftermath of sending him towards the lady. She laments on how horrifying it would be to watch her loved one die at the hands of ferocity, but laments even more at the thought of watching him live a different life with someone other than her. She even gives his death a hopeful spin, that they may meet again in the afterlife or some equivalent, but gives no optimistic spin to him choosing the lady, she even mentions the whole if she can't have him no one can.""

message: I agree with you ladies. I also think that she sends him to the tiger. She loves him fiercely, so fiercely that she cannot bear the thought of someone else having him. Jealousy can make people do ugly things and mix that in with her pure barbaric nature, it makes sense that she would choose for him to stop living versus living with someone else. Mourning would be easier than seeing the person you love happy with another, which is clear by the ways she describes her thoughts and turmoil over the situation.

It's clearly written that she loves him dearly, and his trustworthiness isn't something to consider so heavily since she will lose him heavily. I think she points him to the tiger because of how much more thought she put into the aftermath of sending him towards the lady. She laments on how horrifying it would be to watch her loved one die at the hands of ferocity, but laments even more at the thought of watching him live a different life with someone other than her. She even gives his death a hopeful spin, that they may meet again in the afterlife or some equivalent, but gives no optimistic spin to him choosing the lady, she even mentions the whole if she can't have him no one can."""
Ashley Peterson: "since she will lose him anyway*"
Denise Harris: "I agree with you ladies. I also think that she sends him to the tiger. She loves him fiercely, so fiercely that she cannot bear the thought of someone else having him. Jealousy can make people do ugly things and mix that in with her pure barbaric nature, it makes sense that she would choose for him to stop living versus living with someone else. Mourning would be easier than seeing the person you love happy with another, which is clear by the ways she describes her thoughts and turmoil over the situation."
Denise Harris: "I believe the King would be upset that the rules of his arena were broken. But"
Denise Harris: "But I think he would also revel in the fact that his daughter could be so barbaric. However, he does seem to hold the random chance of fate of the arena in the highest regard so although he loves his daughter above all else I think he may make an example of her. Especially if the people found out what happened"
Ashley Peterson: "Just realized I never answered the second question. I also agree that while the king may feel a bit of pride for his daughter, he holds his beliefs in his chance of fate style of justice so closely to his chest, so he most likely made an example out of his daughter as well."
Denise Harris: "Hey Ashley Peterson! I also wanted to mention the story mention the King's barbaric nature numerous times so it is highly likely that he would punish his daughter."
Ashley Peterson: "Oh definitely! I wrote out a possible response beneath your reiteration. Feel free to add/delete whichever parts! Joyce Brown, do you have any further thoughts about how the king would react? You mentioned he would most likely decide his daughter would be a worthy predecessor while Denise Harris and I believe he would punish her anyway."
Joyce Brown: "I added a brief ending. If everyone is good with it, lets hit submit"

Linda Long: "Hi Patricia Green and Michelle Rivera,"
Linda Long: "I read the story and I am ready for discussion too. Let's decide on a mutual time for this. Thanks,"
Michelle Rivera: "Apologies for my slacking with this, I am also finished now."
Linda Long: "Can we plan on Tuesday the 23rd at 8pm to all meet back here to discuss and answer? Thanks"
Patricia Green: "I just replied to the email, but yes" I can meet back here tomorrow (Tues. at 8pm). "See" you all then!""
Patricia Green: "Hi Linda Long and Michelle Rivera, I am here and ready whenever you both are."
Michelle Rivera: "I am on,"
Patricia Green: "So, we discuss the prompt here and then write it together in the box below?"
Michelle Rivera: "I think so."
Patricia Green: "Ok, that's how I understand it as well. Let's wait a few more minutes to give Julie a chance to join us. Sound good?"
Michelle Rivera: "Yes. and honestly, the first time I read the prompt I thought we were just answering the questions in a method of critical thinking question. Now I am wondering if we are supposed to write an ending"
Patricia Green: "Good point. I thought the same thing about how to answer the questions."
Patricia Green: "It really could be interpreted either way. Just answer questions or write an ending . . . ."
Michelle Rivera: "Yes, potentially something for the research team to work on clarifying...."
Patricia Green: "Definitely"
Patricia Green: "How much longer would you like to wait for Julie before we begin? 5 more minutes?"
Michelle Rivera: "If you can I can, or we could start and she could catch up?"
Michelle Rivera: "I hope she's not back on one of the earlier pages, I just went back to reference and clicked the discussion and was left with a blank page, all these messages were not there."
Linda Long: "So, what do you think about the questions?"
Patricia Green: "Perfect, we are all here."
Linda Long: "Sorry for the delay"
Michelle Rivera: "In terms of just answering I feel like the tiger was behind the door, and later the King puts the daughter to trial..."
Linda Long: "That's exactly what I think as well."
Patricia Green: "No problem. :) So to jump right in, when I read I felt like she sent him to the door with the tiger."
Patricia Green: "Ok, we all thought the tiger!"
Michelle Rivera: "does this mean we are barbaric too?"
Patricia Green: "Ha ha, maybe!"
Patricia Green: "So if the King puts his daughter on trial, does that mean he sets her up with 2 doors as well?"
Linda Long: "lol no, it just seemed like what happened based on her father, and her own jealous nature"
Patricia Green: "Yes, she did seem very jealous. The story led me to believe she would rather nobody have him if she could not."
Michelle Rivera: "from my thoughts I thought yes, he sets up 2 doors for her and lets the trial decide."
Linda Long: "I think so. Even though the story said he loved her so much, I think his barbaric nature would take over his reasoning"
Patricia Green: "Ok, so what happens then?"
Patricia Green: "Do we choose which door she opens?"
Linda Long: "Are we all supposed to write our answers below?"
Michelle Rivera: "I think it's barbaric nature but also slightly just (in a warped way), because as it mentions he treated women and men equally so would feel obliged to treat his daughter the same"
Patricia Green: "Yes, I think so. We were discussing if we write it like answers or finish the story? Thoughts?"
Michelle Rivera: "Good question Julie, we were discussing before you logged on, we are not quite sure if the prompt is looking for just the answers or an ending to be written"
Linda Long: "Yes, that's true as well"
Michelle Rivera: "I'm not sure about the ending if we pick the door for her...personally as a (casual) author I would not want to pick an ending in this case"
Linda Long: "I think we are supposed to surmise or predict what we think happens"
Michelle Rivera: "Okay so maybe we could each write out an answer for the first part of the question and then we edit the response into one?"
Patricia Green: "Ok, that works for me. We can just answer the questions."
Michelle Rivera: "...then the same for the second part?"
Patricia Green: "Yes, lets do that!"

chat_history:
Patricia Green: "Hi everyone! I have read the story and am ready to discuss.  I can log back in later to see if anyone else is ready.  Should we try to figure out a time to all come back and work in here together?"
Linda Long: "Hi Patricia Green and Michelle Rivera,"
Linda Long: "I read the story and I am ready for discussion too. Let's decide on a mutual time for this. Thanks,"
Michelle Rivera: "Apologies for my slacking with this, I am also finished now."
Linda Long: "Can we plan on Tuesday the 23rd at 8pm to all meet back here to discuss and answer? Thanks"
Patricia Green: "I just replied to the email, but yes" I can meet back here tomorrow (Tues. at 8pm). "See" you all then!""
Patricia Green: "Hi Linda Long and Michelle Rivera, I am here and ready whenever you both are."
Michelle Rivera: "I am on,"
Patricia Green: "So, we discuss the prompt here and then write it together in the box below?"
Michelle Rivera: "I think so."
Patricia Green: "Ok, that's how I understand it as well. Let's wait a few more minutes to give Julie a chance to join us. Sound good?"
Michelle Rivera: "Yes. and honestly, the first time I read the prompt I thought we were just answering the questions in a method of critical thinking question. Now I am wondering if we are supposed to write an ending"
Patricia Green: "Good point. I thought the same thing about how to answer the questions."
Patricia Green: "It really could be interpreted either way. Just answer questions or write an ending . . . ."
Michelle Rivera: "Yes, potentially something for the research team to work on clarifying...."
Patricia Green: "Definitely"
Patricia Green: "How much longer would you like to wait for Julie before we begin? 5 more minutes?"
Michelle Rivera: "If you can I can, or we could start and she could catch up?"
Michelle Rivera: "I hope she's not back on one of the earlier pages, I just went back to reference and clicked the discussion and was left with a blank page, all these messages were not there."
Linda Long: "So, what do you think about the questions?"
Patricia Green: "Perfect, we are all here."
Linda Long: "Sorry for the delay"
Michelle Rivera: "In terms of just answering I feel like the tiger was behind the door, and later the King puts the daughter to trial..."
Linda Long: "That's exactly what I think as well."
Patricia Green: "No problem. :) So to jump right in, when I read I felt like she sent him to the door with the tiger."
Patricia Green: "Ok, we all thought the tiger!"
Michelle Rivera: "does this mean we are barbaric too?"
Patricia Green: "Ha ha, maybe!"
Patricia Green: "So if the King puts his daughter on trial, does that mean he sets her up with 2 doors as well?"
Linda Long: "lol no, it just seemed like what happened based on her father, and her own jealous nature"
Patricia Green: "Yes, she did seem very jealous. The story led me to believe she would rather nobody have him if she could not."
Michelle Rivera: "from my thoughts I thought yes, he sets up 2 doors for her and lets the trial decide."
Linda Long: "I think so. Even though the story said he loved her so much, I think his barbaric nature would take over his reasoning"
Patricia Green: "Ok, so what happens then?"
Patricia Green: "Do we choose which door she opens?"
Linda Long: "Are we all supposed to write our answers below?"
Michelle Rivera: "I think it's barbaric nature but also slightly just (in a warped way), because as it mentions he treated women and men equally so would feel obliged to treat his daughter the same"
Patricia Green: "Yes, I think so. We were discussing if we write it like answers or finish the story? Thoughts?"
Michelle Rivera: "Good question Julie, we were discussing before you logged on, we are not quite sure if the prompt is looking for just the answers or an ending to be written"
Linda Long: "Yes, that's true as well"
Michelle Rivera: "I'm not sure about the ending if we pick the door for her...personally as a (casual) author I would not want to pick an ending in this case"
Linda Long: "I think we are supposed to surmise or predict what we think happens"
Michelle Rivera: "Okay so maybe we could each write out an answer for the first part of the question and then we edit the response into one?"
Patricia Green: "Ok, that works for me. We can just answer the questions."
Michelle Rivera: "...then the same for the second part?"
Patricia Green: "Yes, lets do that!"
Linda Long: "Yes, I'd rather keep it simple lol"
Michelle Rivera: "I like the "doom""
Linda Long: "is that too much?"
Patricia Green: "No I think it is good."
Michelle Rivera: "I don't think it is too much."
Michelle Rivera: "Is the second sentence for part 2 okay?"
Linda Long: "Should we mention that love didn't weigh in to either of their decisions?"
Patricia Green: "I like it. It draws from the story."
Michelle Rivera: "Probably yes"
Patricia Green: "Good idea."
Linda Long: "I'm not sure how to word it, but I think their barbaric nature made them irrational and maybe incapable of love? Something like that..."
Michelle Rivera: "I mean I think it states that the king does love the daughter at some point though."
Michelle Rivera: "Maybe not to enough of a degree not to put her to trial...but he does love her, just like to a degree she loved the man"
Patricia Green: "Maybe write that the king, despite his love for his daughter, could only act in a barbaric manner"
Patricia Green: "He was tied to his own idealistic principles?"
Michelle Rivera: "yes"
Patricia Green: "I like it! Good sentemce."
Patricia Green: "sentence*"
Linda Long: "There, lol. what do you girls think?"
Michelle Rivera: "I like it..."
Linda Long: "So, we title it SUBMITTED and that's it, right?"
Patricia Green: "Good job!"
Patricia Green: "Yes, I believe so and then fill out the survey thing back on canvas saying we completed the assignment. And that's it right?"
Michelle Rivera: "Yes, and I know that we are going with just answering but should you want to see an ending I was messing around with I would gladly share (we don't have to submit that necessarily)"
Michelle Rivera: "I believe that is all the survey and canvas yes"
Patricia Green: "Sure, share it. I am curious."
Linda Long: "sure, let's see it"
Linda Long: "I like it"
Patricia Green: "Yes!! Well done."
Patricia Green: "I can see it clearly."
Linda Long: "Yes it fits well with the story"
Michelle Rivera: "yay, lol."
Linda Long: "We could leave it in if you want. We've answered the questions and then some. I don't think it would hurt. What do you girls think?"
Patricia Green: "If you would like, we can leave both our answers and your ending. That way we have both options covered. But if you'd rather not that's okay too."
Patricia Green: "I agree, Linda Long. If you are okay with that, Michelle Rivera?"
Michelle Rivera: "I feel the flow doesn't entirely match the original story, but I felt it was awkwardly written and okay. We can add (ending) before it?"
Linda Long: "I say leave it in. It's well-written and adds depth to the answers."
Michelle Rivera: "Good with the parentheses?"
Patricia Green: "Good idea. And I agree that original story was very awkwardly written. The syntax was strange."
Linda Long: "It might not add to the style in which it was written, but what you predicted to happen fits well with the story in my opinion"

message: I agree with you Lillian Flores about it depending on someone, but I feel that it is up to the person reading the story and reflecting on the actions of the characters. In this case, the princess was jealous of the girl and she was also semi-barbaric like her father, so I feel she would have chosen the door with the tiger for the man. If I go with my own emotions, even though the author said not to base it on that, I would think that the princess would make the right choice with the right door and let him marry the man.  Although, would the man trust the princess enough and choose the same door as she indicated? So behind the right door would be the tiger.  They are both semibarbaric, so the King would most likely be disappointed at first, but either way, he got what he wanted and that was to keep his daughter away from this man. In this case, either sentence would be justice in his eyes.

topic: Part 1: Discuss what would happens next and why, providing evidence or logic. What is behind the door, the lady of the tiger?  Part 2: Later, the King discovers that his daughter had broken the law, by first finding out what was behind the doors & then signaling to her lover which door to open. What would the king do, and why? Do NOT write fiction, but rather speculate and provide support.
message: Hi everyone! I think what happens next is that the princess let her lover marry the woman. The reason why I think she would do that is because she loves the man (as they had made each other the center of each others universe) and she would rather see him alive then feel guilty that she is the reason why he dies (she had nightmares of her lover being killed by the tiger). The king represent determinism and barbarism by having chance dictate one's choice (which he had demonstrated in the arena.)  The princess represented free will and progressivism because she actively went out of her way to know which door held which. I do not think a good lover will put harm's way to their love ones. The princess lost the man regardless of which door she choose but at least she can fulfill her role as a lover to never put harms way in his direction and not let the barbaric nature from her father's bloodline to overcome her moral compass.

message: My first thought was that the Princess would send her lover to the tiger (because she is like her father and seems to spend a lot more time dwelling on what would happen if he chose the door with the lady than what would happen if he got the tiger), but Michelle makes a good point - that she represents free will in opposition to her father (by finding out what was behind each door). I do think that a lot of this story rests in what the reader brings to it - whether the reader thinks that the Princess would send her lover to death or give him a life without her, depends upon the reader's perception of the world and of the context of the story, rather than just the story itself. Now, I do think that the King would alter the punishment for her daughter when he finds out that she broke the law, simply because he loves her so much and I don't think he would send her to the arena (although I think that would make a more interesting story in my opinion).

What would the king do, and why? Do NOT write fiction, but rather speculate and provide support.
message: Part Two:  I believe the King would send his daughter to the tribunal, because even though he loves her and she is the apple of his eye, he is illustrated to be set in his ways.  He would not make an exception for her because he feels that he needs to establish his power over the citizens of the kingdom.  If he subjects his daughter to the same punishment, then he is proving his stance and making an example of her to his kingdom.  I believe she would find a way to outwit the King, maybe with the help of her lover who she granted life to in part one.

message: Part One: The princess seemed more threatened and bothered by the image of her lover going into the arms of another, than by the image of a tiger tearing him apart. I don't remember her exact words, but she thinks him dying quickly if the tiger is behind the door is a better fate for him. I'm not a fan of the barbaric ancestry and tendencies this text brings up, but it seems to be given as the reason for the King and Princess to act cruel and savagely. Therefore, I do think that that behind the door the Princess motioned to is the tiger. The story reads to me as if the Princess would rather have her lover to herself in perpetuity (in her mind) by killing him off now instead of see him with someone else.

The Princess grappled with her thoughts and instincts, feeling jealous and thinking about sending her lover to his death rather than see him with another woman.  She ended up indicating the door which held the beautiful woman because she realized that she couldn't live with the knowledge that she had sent her lover to his ruin.  Deciding that she would rather see him alive, she shows him which door to pick."
Helen Howard: "Part Two:  I believe the King would send his daughter to the tribunal, because even though he loves her and she is the apple of his eye, he is illustrated to be set in his ways.  He would not make an exception for her because he feels that he needs to establish his power over the citizens of the kingdom.  If he subjects his daughter to the same punishment, then he is proving his stance and making an example of her to his kingdom.  I believe she would find a way to outwit the King, maybe with the help of her lover who she granted life to in part one."
Kathryn Bell: "I think she tells him to go to the right but he goes to the left, finding the lady behind the door. In that moment realizes that she led him to his death. The Princess then has to face the fact that he found out she would rather see him dead than with the lady."
Kathryn Bell: "Although the King is one that like to follows the rules and has a very barbaric side, he doesn't send his daughter to the tribunal. Instead he makes her live with the agony of living without her love and while facing the fact of her character."
Nicole Gonzalez: "Part One: The princess seemed more threatened and bothered by the image of her lover going into the arms of another, than by the image of a tiger tearing him apart. I don't remember her exact words, but she thinks him dying quickly if the tiger is behind the door is a better fate for him. I'm not a fan of the barbaric ancestry and tendencies this text brings up, but it seems to be given as the reason for the King and Princess to act cruel and savagely. Therefore, I do think that that behind the door the Princess motioned to is the tiger. The story reads to me as if the Princess would rather have her lover to herself in perpetuity (in her mind) by killing him off now instead of see him with someone else."
Nicole Gonzalez: "Part One con't: Oops, sent the rest before finishing this thought. I think the lover goes to the door on the left instead of the door on the right, thinking on her barbaric" nature and that she'd likely betray him  and finds a lady instead of the tiger. I'm assuming even though he knows her  it would leave him in shock knowing that the Princess would want him dead if she cannot keep him to herself.""
Nicole Gonzalez: "Part Two: I think if the King discovered the truth and that the Princess had broken the law, she would be sent to the same fate as her lover. Having to choose between the two  he would ultimately make her choose which door just like other so-called criminals." doors. The King thinks himself fair and seems to care a great deal about maintaining his just" rule and appearance. I do think that even if he loves his daughter"
Lillian Roberts: "Part 1: I think that the princess will choose the door with the lady because even though she is jealous of her beauty, in the end she knows her lover loved her and could not live with the pain of killing her love. I also believe that the lover trusts her and chooses the door she picks, leaving him alive and married to the other lady."
Lillian Roberts: "Part 2: I believe that the king will not make an example of his daughter for the kingdom, as this would display a bad reputation for the royal family. Instead, I believe the king will keep the knowledge of his daughter's crime to himself with the knowledge that he sent her love on a different path and she can no longer have him."
Lillian Roberts: "Hello Helen Howard, I agree with your thoughts on the decision for part 1, but I don't believe the king would amplify the mistakes of his daughter by sending her to the tribunal as it would make the royal family look bad in the eyes of the public if everyone knew of her crimes."
Helen Howard: "I enjoyed reading all of your perspectives.  Nicole Gonzalez- I also found the idea of barbarism" kind of unsettling... I guess it was a pretty common theme in story telling in the "old  but reading from my 21st century perspective days"  it feels like labeling the society as "other" or "bad".""
Nicole Gonzalez: "Hi Helen Howard! I feel this text is meant to unsettle in a way. It wasn't just the barbarism but also the mention of ancestry and blood that made me think it was fatalistic in a way. Kind of like the King and Princess were destined to act in cruel ways. I'm glad that someone else picked up on it too and I really liked your point that it does feel labeling a society in sweeping terms."

Based on how the Princess is described as barbaric" like her father  I think the King sends his daughter into the tribunal as well. He seems set in his ways and seems to value power over logic." and how she struggles between the two options of leading him to his death or leading him to a life. Part two: as mentioned earlier"
Teresa Stewart: "Hi Kathryn Bell! I am curious to know why you think the lover would not follow the princess's instructions to open the door on the right? While the princess definitely felt untrustworthy to me, I did not get a sense that the lover felt that from her."
Sandra Coleman: "Part 1:  I believe that the Princess indicated for her lover to choose the door with the other lady behind it, because her love for him was strong.  Her relationship with him wasn't only passionate feelings, but truly a deep love, that is why it pained the Princess so much to think of her lover with another woman.  I believe that the young man trusted the Princess, because he knew her very well.  He knew that she would defy her father and find the answer to save him.  That's why he looked to her for help. Shirley Morris: "Part 1: I believe that he chooses the door that the Princess gives him the hint to choose. When he opens the door, the lady is there because the Princess has love that very strong for him. She knows that she would rather know that he is alive and happy than send him to his end."
Shirley Morris: "Part 2: With how the King wants to assert his power over his kingdom and people, I believe he would make an example out of his daughter and send her to same fate as her lover. He didn't take her feelings about her lover into consideration so that shows how brutal his mind and rule is."
Douglas Jackson: "Part 1: I think the princess hints to him the door with the lover. She is described as only semi barberous and so by having her show mercy to her former lover she provides a foil of free will to the Barbarous Kings fate based judicious system."

message: Hi Helen Howard! I actually had the same question as I had never heard this story before. So I did some research! This short story was written by Frank Stockton in 1882. topic: Part 1: What happens next? What is behind the door, the lady or the tiger?  Part 2: Later, the King discovers that his daughter has broken the law.  How does the King respond? What happens?
message: I think it is entirely possible for the tiger to be behind the door, as the story indicates that she is jealous of the lady and she has a barbaric spirit like her father. However, as Katie said, I don't think she could have watched the tiger eat him if she loved him so much. Also, the end of the story says that she knew he would ask her, just as he knew she would take it upon herself to find out, so I think that she would not be able to lead him to the door with the tiger and live with that, especially if she thought about what she would tell him days before.

Katie: "So regarding part 1 of the question, I think the lady is behind the door!"
Natalie: "That's what I thought to or how I interpreted the ending"
Katie: "If she really loves him, she should want him to be with someone else and alive rather than dead!"
Rebecca: "Did you guys already read the story? It won't move past the part of four questions for me."
Katie: "What about you, Rebecca?"
Natalie: "It was strange because it seems the daughter is jealous of the lady behind the door. so its an interesting twist"
Katie: "Oh, sorry! Yes I read it"
Katie: "Rebecca, it was a bit glitchy with me at times and I refreshed and logged back in"
Natalie: "Oh yeah Rebecca, in order to get past page 8, you have to form 5 questions with the tiles on bottom of screen"
Natalie: "Hint I _____him?"
Natalie: "then click submit"
Rebecca: "I tried to read it before 7 but it's stuck on that one part"
Natalie: "then click on the checkmark button"
Natalie: "I had to ask my spouse for help"
Natalie: "head in hands"
Katie: "Oh, yeah! You make up the questions and then can advance!"
Rebecca: "Yeah I put questions, I'll refresh and try again"
Natalie: "Each time you submit, the lady talks back to you and her icon changes."
Rebecca: "Hm it's still not working. Sorry guys I'm trying"
Natalie: "Which browser did you use?"
Natalie: "It took me 10 tried. Then I got it"
Natalie: "It doesn't matter the combo of the questions"
Rebecca: "I'm in google chrome"
Katie: "Yes, it has to be chrome or firefox"
Rebecca: "Ok it's finally working. I'll read the next part quickly and then I'll be good to keep going. Sorry guys, thanks for your help"
Katie: "No worries!"
Rebecca: "Okay, I agree, I think the lady is behind the door."
Katie: "So it definitely seems like the princess hates the lady behind the door. But if it were me, I couldn't stand to see the man I love being eaten by a tiger."
Natalie: "Do you think the lady is more beautiful than the princess?"
Katie: "I'm not sure. They're probably equally beautiful and just jealous :)"
Natalie: "ha ha"
Rebecca: "I think it is entirely possible for the tiger to be behind the door, as the story indicates that she is jealous of the lady and she has a barbaric spirit like her father. However, as Katie said, I don't think she could have watched the tiger eat him if she loved him so much. Also, the end of the story says that she knew he would ask her, just as he knew she would take it upon herself to find out, so I think that she would not be able to lead him to the door with the tiger and live with that, especially if she thought about what she would tell him days before."
Katie: "Well said, Rebecca"
Natalie: "Good point you made Rebecca"
Katie: "Regarding part 2 of the question, what do you think the king does to his daughter?"
Rebecca: "I think the king would subject her to the same law as everyone else and expect her fate to be decided in the arena."
Katie: "Since he's barbaric...maybe he puts her in the ring to face her own doors? :("
Katie: "Okay, me too! Sorry there's a bit of a delay on my end."
Rebecca: "If he knew his daughter truly loved that man but sent him to the arena because of his barbaric nature, I don't think he would extend any grace to his daughter, even though the story told us that he treasures her."
Natalie: "That's what I thought as well. I remember the description of the King being barbaric with his punishments and I think he would put his daughter in front of the doors as well"
Katie: "Yep."
Rebecca: "Do you think that the king would be tempted to do the same thing she did, though, and find out which door was which?"
Natalie: "I could be wrong but I think the daughter's door opened up to being with her lover?"
Natalie: "There appears to be descriptions of her seeing her lover's face?"
Katie: "Not really, no. Considering they mention how barbaric he is. I feel like he's a by-the-book sort of guy"
Katie: "That was in response to Rebecca's question."
Rebecca: "Where did you see those descriptions, Natalie?"
Katie: "Yeah, did they actually put the King's daughter in the arena in the story?"
Rebecca: "Yeah, I think you're right. But it would be interesting if her lover ended up being behind the door she chose. Although I think the story said that it was people in the king's court that decide who goes behind the door, not the king."
Rebecca: "So I'm not sure if the king would've had a hand in putting her lover behind the door."
Rebecca: "But it would be interesting if the princess's actions in breaking the law made her father realize just how much she loved the man (if she did tell him of the door with the lady). So maybe he could've used his influence to put her lover behind the door, that way he could still abide by his own law but also extend love to his daughter."
Katie: "I honestly found the writing style in the story kind of confusing?"
Katie: "Anyone else?"
Rebecca: "Me too I had to reread the first couple pages several times before I understood what was going on."
Katie: "Same."

Also, the end of the story says that she knew he would ask her, just as he knew she would take it upon herself to find out, so I think that she would not be able to lead him to the door with the tiger and live with that, especially if she thought about what she would tell him days before."

Natalie: "Good point you made Rebecca"
Katie: "Regarding part 2 of the question, what do you think the king does to his daughter?"
Rebecca: "I think the king would subject her to the same law as everyone else and expect her fate to be decided in the arena."
Katie: "Since he's barbaric...maybe he puts her in the ring to face her own doors? :("
Katie: "Okay, me too! Sorry there's a bit of a delay on my end."
Rebecca: "If he knew his daughter truly loved that man but sent him to the arena because of his barbaric nature, I don't think he would extend any grace to his daughter, even though the story told us that he treasures her."

Katie: "Yep."
Rebecca: "Do you think that the king would be tempted to do the same thing she did, though, and find out which door was which?"
Natalie: "I could be wrong but I think the daughter's door opened up to being with her lover?"
Natalie: "There appears to be descriptions of her seeing her lover's face?"

Katie: "That was in response to Rebecca's question."

Katie: "Yeah, did they actually put the King's daughter in the arena in the story?"
Rebecca: "Yeah, I think you're right. But it would be interesting if her lover ended up being behind the door she chose. Although I think the story said that it was people in the king's court that decide who goes behind the door, not the king."
Rebecca: "So I'm not sure if the king would've had a hand in putting her lover behind the door."
Rebecca: "But it would be interesting if the princess's actions in breaking the law made her father realize just how much she loved the man (if she did tell him of the door with the lady). So maybe he could've used his influence to put her lover behind the door, that way he could still abide by his own law but also extend love to his daughter."

Katie: "Same."

Rebecca: "I guess that was all we had to do? I don't know if there's anything else to discuss"
Katie: "Okay, cool"
